#Text=Asmat Begum
#Text=Asmat Begum ( died 1621 ) was the wife of Mirza Ghias Beg , the Prime minister of the Mughal emperor Jahangir , and the mother of Mughal empress Nur Jahan , the power behind the emperor . [ 1 ]
#Text=Asmat Begum was also the paternal grandmother of Empress Mumtaz Mahal , for whom the Taj Mahal was built .
#Text=Family
#Text=Asmat
#Text=Begum was the daughter of Mirza Ala-ud-Daula Aqa Mulla [ 2 ] and a member of the illustrious Aqa Mulla clan . [ 3 ]
#Text=She was a wise , well-educated , accomplished and highly cultured lady . [ 4 ]
#Text=She had a brother , Ibrahim Khan , who served as the governor of Bengal during Emperor Jahangir 's reign . [ 5 ]
#Text=Marriage
#Text=Asmat
#Text=Begum was married to the Persian noble , Mirza Ghiyas Beg , the youngest son of Khvajeh Mohammad-Sharif , a Persian noble of Tehran and a vizier to the governor of Khorasan . [ 6 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=The couple had four children together : Mohammad Sharif , Asaf Khan , Sahlia and Mehr-un-Nissa ( later Empress Nur Jahan ) .
#Text=For unknown reasons , Ghias Beg and his family had suffered a reversal in fortune in 1576 and soon found circumstances intolerable in their homeland of Persia .
#Text=Drawn to the favourable climate of Emperor Akbar 's court in Agra , the family decided to migrate to India . [ 3 ]
#Text=Ghias Beg became a trusted minister under both Akbar and his son Jahangir and was awarded the title of ' I'timad-ud-Daulah ' ( " Pillar of the State " ) for his services . [ 8 ]
#Text=However , while serving as the diwan to an amir-ul-umara in 1607 , Ghias Beg was charged with embezzling Rs . 50,000 , which led to a decrease in his rank and status at court . [ 9 ]
#Text=In 1611 , Asmat Begum 's second daughter , Mehr-un-Nissa , caught the eye of the reigning emperor Jahangir at the palace Meena Bazaar .
#Text=The emperor proposed immediately and they were married within the same year . [ 10 ]
#Text=This marriage again led to a dramatic rise in the fortunes of Asmat Begum and Ghias Beg 's family .
#Text=Ghias Beg was given a substantial increase in mansab and made wazir of the whole dominion in 1611 .
#Text=Likewise , their sons Asaf Khan and Itiqad Khan were also given high positions and mansab s in the empire . [ 11 ]
#Text=Political role
#Text=at the Mughal court
#Text=Mehr-un-Nissa ( titled ' Nur Jahan ' after her marriage ) became Jahangir 's most beloved and influential wife and soon became the real power behind the throne after their marriage .
#Text=Nur Jahan formed a faction known as the junta which comprised her family members and her step-son , Prince Khurram ( the future emperor Shah Jahan ) . [ 12 ]
#Text=This faction , led by Nur Jahan , took control of the government as Jahangir became increasingly addicted to opium and alcohol . [ 10 ]
#Text=Asmat Begum , who was a wise and patient counsel in her own right , must certainly have been the nurturing hub of the junta in its heyday . [ 13 ]
#Text=She is also known to have taken a politically active role in the affairs of the court and served as a mother-figure to Jahangir and a counselor to Nur Jahan . [ 14 ]
#Text=However , Asmat Begum is perhaps best known for having invented the famous rose perfume called Jahangiri-itr , which was described by Jahangir as the discovery of his reign . [ 15 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=Cenotaph of Asmat Begum alongside that of her husband Mirza Ghias Beg .
#Text=Asmat Begum died in October 1621 in Agra . [ 16 ]

#Text=Upon her death , her son-in-law Jahangir , who was extremely fond of her , wrote : " Without exaggeration , in purity of disposition and in wisdom and the excellencies that are the ornament of women
